pyinterpolate.idw package#

Submodules#

pyinterpolate.idw.idw module#

Distance calculation functions.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

inverse_distance_weighting(known_points: ndarray, unknown_location: Iterable, number_of_neighbours=-1, power=2.0) → float[source]#

Inverse Distance Weighting with a given set of points and an unknown location.

Parameters:

  • known_points (numpy array) ‚Äì Array MxN, where M is a number of rows (points) and N is the number of columns, where last column represents value of a known point. (It could be multidimensional data).

  • unknown_location (Iterable) ‚Äì Array or list with coordinates of the unknown point. It‚Äôs length is N-1 (number of known_points columns - the value column). Unknown location dimension should be the same as known_points dimension, if not, then new dimension is added once - vector of points [x, y] becomes [[x, y]] for 2-dimensional data.

  • number_of_neighbours (int, default = -1) ‚Äì If default value (-1) then all known points will be used to estimate value at the unknown location. Can be any number within the limits [2, length(known_points)],

  • power (float, default = 2.) ‚Äì Power value must be larger or equal to 0, controls weight assigned to each known point. Larger power means stronger influence of closest points to the unknown point, but it gets smaller faster.

Returns:

result ‚Äì Estimated value.

Return type:

float

Raises:

ValueError ‚Äì

  • Power parameter set to be smaller than 0. * Less than 2 neighbours or more than the number of known_points neighbours are given in number_of_neighbours parameter.
